Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--isotope-enabled TRAnsient Climate Evolution of the last 21,000 years (iTRACE21)----Understanding Deglacial Climate/Isotope Changes Using iCESM
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research investigates the mechanisms of climate changes during the last deglaciation (21,000 to 11,000 years ago) using a state-of-the-art isotope-enabled Earth System Model (ESM). The major scientific questions to be addressed in this project are: (1) What are the relationships between the isotopic composition of water and climate changes over the globe? (2) How does the climate system respond to changing climate forcings of the last deglaciation, and what is the contribution from each forcing: insolation, atmospheric greenhouse gases, continental ice sheets, and meltwater? The simulations will allow the study of the continuous evolution and abrupt changes of climate from interannual to orbital time scales. The type of transient simulation marks a transformative breakthrough in model-data comparison, allowing for direct data and model time series comparisons, and will have a significant impact on future paleoclimate studies using both models and observations. The proposed simulations will have a ground breaking impact on research in the paleoclimate community, providing model data for a number of other community projects. It will lay a foundation for a systematic test of future generations of ESMs with coupled cryosphere and biogeochemical models.

Specifically, the new version of NCAR's community ESM (CESM), enabled with water isotope tracers, will be run in fully-coupled mode for the period 21,000 to 11,000 years ago. The main simulation will be forced by prescribed changes in insolation, atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, continental ice sheets, sea level, and meltwater, while sensitivity simulations will investigate the effect of the different forcings separately. This simulation will be run at a higher resolution (2 degrees in the atmosphere and 1 degree in the ocean) than the previous generation transient model run with CCSM3 (3 degrees). Furthermore, stable water isotope tracers have been included in the atmosphere, land-surface, ocean, and sea-ice models and will be tested first for the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM, 21,000 years ago) and present climate time slices before being run in transient mode for the last deglaciation. One central task of the proposed transient simulations is to explore a new paradigm of model-data comparison in close collaboration with the data community, focusing on direct time series comparisons of isotopes. The simulation of isotope time series will improve paleoclimate model-data comparison significantly, because it will reduce the uncertainties arising from both the inference of isotopes and the absolute chronology of the proxy records. The project will provide the basis for graduate research for students from the University of Wisconsin and Oregon State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global climate has undergone dramatic change over the last 21,000 years accompanied by large changes in insolation, atmospheric greenhouse gases, continental ice sheets, and meltwater fluxes from the retreating ice sheets. Superimposed on the background climate evolution are abrupt climate change events of the North Atlantic region, such as the Heinrich Stadial Event 1, (HS1), the Bolling-Allerod warming (BA), and the Younger Dryas cooling (YD), and the abrupt events of the monsoon-ecosystem. The large magnitude of signals and the availability of extensive proxy climate records make this period an excellent target for investigating the mechanisms underlying climate change and for the evaluation of an Earth System Model (ESM) for simulating large climate variations.

Natural archives of past climates such as ice cores, marine and lake sediments, and cave speleothems (water isotopes (δ18O, δD), carbon isotopes (δ14C, δ13C), and other geotracers (Pa/Th) and Nd)) provide ′proxies′ for instrumental measurements. An obstacle for the evaluation of an ESM against these paleoclimate observations has been that climate variables simulated by ESMs cannot be compared directly with proxy records. The project took advantage of the newly developed isotope-enabled, state-or-the-art Community Earth System Model (iCESM). This initiative allowed for better interpretation of the forcings and feedbacks on the climate evolution over this time period and a more complete model-data intercomparison: data informing modeling and modeling informing data.

We completed the first deglaciation (21ka-11ka) simulation (iTrace run) in the water-isotope enabled iCESM that included the evolving orbital insolation, atmospheric greenhouse gases, continental ice sheets, and meltwater fluxes. In parallel, we completed three sensitivity forcing factor experiments including the evolution of the ice sheets and bathymetry, then additionally with the orbital forcing, and finally additionally with the greenhouse gas concentrations. Our iTrace run reproduced the major features of the deglaciation evolution for several key benchmarks, not only qualitatively, but also quantitatively as a direct model-data comparison for the water isotopes. For example, the deglacial evolution of water isotopes shows a strong resemblance between the model simulation and proxy data records from: the Greenland ice cores, Hulu cave speleothems, and Antarctic ice cores, including the HS1, BA, and YD events and the overall long-term trends. In particular, our iTrace run is able to simulate these key benchmarks directly and quantitatively. The spatial pattern of the climate and isotope response at HS1 and BA also show characteristic features of the bipolar see-saw response at HS1 and a largely global symmetric response at the BA relative to the LGM. Furthermore, the forcing mechanism of these benchmark responses can be isolated in the forcing factor experiments. For example, the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) shows a decrease due to the ice sheet retreat at 14ka, which is then compensated by the increase caused by the increased CO2, with the orbital forcing playing little role.

The water isotope-enabled code (iCESM1.2) used in the iTrace project is now available to the community on github. A paper describing this implementation in CESM has been published in the American Geophysical Union Journal of Advances in Modeling Earth Systems. Moreover, by making the data from the iTrace simulations easily downloadable by the research community (i.e. geology, paleoceanography, paleoecology, etc), this project will continue to significantly enhance our understanding of geotracers in the representation of past climate changes and possible mechanisms for explaining reconstructions of the climate evolution of the deglaciation.
